Ubuntu / Linux Essential Command Guide for Developers
This document is a no-nonsense, practical command reference for Ubuntu and Linux users. If you touch
servers, containers, code, or terminals, these commands are mandatory knowledge.
1. File & Folder Management
pwd → Show current directory
ls → List files
ls -la → List all files with permissions
cd folder_name → Enter folder
cd .. → Go back one level
cd ~ → Go to home directory
mkdir folder → Create folder
mkdir -p parent/child/grandchild → Create nested folders
touch file.txt → Create empty file
cp file.txt dest/ → Copy file
cp -r folder dest/ → Copy folder
mv file.txt newname.txt → Rename file
mv file.txt folder/ → Move file
rm file.txt → Delete file
rm -r folder → Delete folder
rm -rf folder → Force delete (danger)
stat file.txt → File details
tree → Folder structure view
2. Locate Files & Folders
find / -name file.txt → Search file system
find . -type f → Find files
find . -type d → Find folders
locate file.txt → Fast search (needs updatedb)
updatedb → Update locate database
which python → Command binary location
whereis python → Binary, source, man page
3. File Viewing & Editing
cat file.txt → View file
less file.txt → Scroll view
head file.txt → First 10 lines
tail file.txt → Last 10 lines
tail -f log.txt → Live log view
nano file.txt → Edit (beginner)
vim file.txt → Edit (pro)
code . → Open VS Code
4. Permissions & Ownership
chmod 755 file.sh → Change permissions
chmod +x script.sh → Make executable
chown user:user file.txt → Change owner
ls -l → View permissions
5. Package Management (APT)
sudo apt update → Refresh repo
sudo apt upgrade → Upgrade system
sudo apt install git → Install package

sudo apt remove git → Remove package
sudo apt purge git → Remove config too
apt search nginx → Search package
apt show nginx → Package info
sudo apt autoremove → Cleanup
6. Install .deb File (Downloaded from Website)
cd ~/Downloads
sudo dpkg -i app.deb → Install deb
sudo apt -f install → Fix dependencies
sudo dpkg -r app → Remove deb app
7. System Info & Monitoring
uname -a → Kernel info
lsb_release -a → OS info
df -h → Disk usage
du -sh folder → Folder size
free -h → RAM usage
top / htop → Process monitor
uptime → System runtime
whoami → Current user
8. Networking
ip a → Network interfaces
ip route → Routing table
ping google.com → Test internet
curl url → API call
wget url → Download file
ss -tuln → Open ports
netstat -tuln → Legacy port list
9. Process Management
ps aux → All processes
kill PID → Kill process
kill -9 PID → Force kill
pkill process → Kill by name
bg / fg → Background / foreground
10. Environment & Shell
env → Environment variables
export VAR=value → Set variable
echo $VAR → Read variable
history → Command history
clear → Clear terminal
alias ll='ls -la' → Shortcut
source ~/.bashrc → Reload config
11. Compression & Archives
tar -czvf file.tar.gz folder/
tar -xzvf file.tar.gz
zip -r file.zip folder/
unzip file.zip
12. Disk & Mount
lsblk → Disk list

mount → Mounted disks
umount /dev/sda1
13. Git (Developer Mandatory)
git clone repo_url
git status
git add .
git commit -m 'msg'
git push
git pull
git branch
git checkout branch
14. Docker (Modern Dev Mandatory)
docker --version
docker ps
docker ps -a
docker images
docker run image
docker stop container
docker rm container
docker rmi image
docker-compose up -d
15. Power Commands (Danger Zone)
sudo su → Root shell
shutdown now
reboot
history -c → Clear history
rm -rf / → NEVER RUN
Final Note
If you don’t know these commands, you are not a serious Linux developer yet. Master these and Linux
becomes a weapon, not an obstacle.

Git Cheat Sheet (Terminal)
Setup
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
Starting a Project
git init                # Initialize a new repo
git clone <url>         # Clone an existing repo
Basic Workflow
git status              # See repo status
git add <file>          # Stage a file
git add .               # Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg"     # Commit with message
git push origin main    # Push changes to remote
git pull origin main    # Pull latest changes
Branching
git branch              # List branches
git branch new-branch   # Create branch
git checkout new-branch # Switch branch
git checkout -b feature # Create + switch
git merge feature       # Merge branch into current
git branch -d feature   # Delete branch
Undo & Fix
git reset --hard HEAD~1     # Undo last commit (dangerous)
git reset --soft HEAD~1     # Undo last commit but keep changes staged
git restore <file>          # Discard changes in a file
git checkout <commit_id>    # Move to old commit (detached HEAD)
Stash
git stash               # Stash current changes
git stash list          # Show stashes
git stash apply         # Reapply last stash
git stash drop          # Delete last stash
Advanced
git log --oneline --graph   # Compact commit history
git diff                    # See unstaged changes
git remote -v               # List remotes
git fetch                   # Fetch remote changes (no merge)
git cherry-pick <commit_id> # Apply specific commit

git rebase -i HEAD~3        # Interactive rebase (edit last 3 commits)
Pro Tips
Use git status often — it’s your best friend.
Keep commit messages short & meaningful.
Push & pull regularly to avoid conflicts.
Use branches for new features → merge → delete branch.

1. File & Folder Management
pwd → Show current directory
ls → List files
ls -la → List all files with permissions
cd folder_name → Enter folder
cd .. → Go back one level
cd ~ → Go to home directory
mkdir folder → Create folder
mkdir -p parent/child/grandchild → Create nested folders
touch file.txt → Create empty file
cp file.txt dest/ → Copy file
cp -r folder dest/ → Copy folder
mv file.txt newname.txt → Rename file
mv file.txt folder/ → Move file
rm file.txt → Delete file
rm -r folder → Delete folder
rm -rf folder → Force delete (danger)
stat file.txt → File details
tree → Folder structure view
2. Locate Files & Folders
find / -name file.txt → Search file system
find . -type f → Find files
find . -type d → Find folders
locate file.txt → Fast search (needs updatedb)
updatedb → Update locate database
which python → Command binary location
whereis python → Binary, source, man page
3. File Viewing & Editing
cat file.txt → View file
less file.txt → Scroll view
head file.txt → First 10 lines
tail file.txt → Last 10 lines
tail -f log.txt → Live log view
nano file.txt → Edit (beginner)
vim file.txt → Edit (pro)
code . → Open VS Code
4. Permissions & Ownership
chmod 755 file.sh → Change permissions
chmod +x script.sh → Make executable
chown user:user file.txt → Change owner
ls -l → View permissions
5. Package Management (APT)
sudo apt update → Refresh repo
sudo apt upgrade → Upgrade system
sudo apt install git → Install package

018ec457-b0bf-4020-997c-06551129a652.chunk_text:
sudo apt remove git → Remove package
sudo apt purge git → Remove config too
apt search nginx → Search package
apt show nginx → Package info
sudo apt autoremove → Cleanup

sudo dpkg -r app → Remove deb app

lsb_release -a → OS info
df -h → Disk usage
du -sh folder → Folder size
free -h → RAM usage
top / htop → Process monitor
uptime → System runtime
whoami → Current user

ip a → Network interfaces
ip route → Routing table
ping google.com → Test internet
curl url → API call
wget url → Download file
ss -tuln → Open ports
netstat -tuln → Legacy port list

ps aux → All processes
kill PID → Kill process
kill -9 PID → Force kill
pkill process → Kill by name
bg / fg → Background / foreground
10. Environment & Shell
env → Environment variables
export VAR=value → Set variable
echo $VAR → Read variable
history → Command history
clear → Clear terminal
alias ll='ls -la' → Shortcut
source ~/.bashrc → Reload config
11. Compression & Archives
tar -czvf file.tar.gz folder/
tar -xzvf file.tar.gz
zip -r file.zip folder/
unzip file.zip

lsblk → Disk list

5308a1fb-e245-4858-9a5b-4f3a5a476496.chunk_text:
Git Cheat Sheet (Terminal)
Setup
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
Starting a Project
git init                # Initialize a new repo
git clone <url>         # Clone an existing repo
Basic Workflow
git status              # See repo status
git add <file>          # Stage a file
git add .               # Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg"     # Commit with message
git push origin main    # Push changes to remote
git pull origin main    # Pull latest changes
Branching
git branch              # List branches
git branch new-branch   # Create branch
git checkout new-branch # Switch branch
git checkout -b feature # Create + switch
git merge feature       # Merge branch into current
git branch -d feature   # Delete branch
Undo & Fix
git reset --hard HEAD~1     # Undo last commit (dangerous)
git reset --soft HEAD~1     # Undo last commit but keep changes staged
git restore <file>          # Discard changes in a file
git checkout <commit_id>    # Move to old commit (detached HEAD)
Stash
git stash               # Stash current changes
git stash list          # Show stashes
git stash apply         # Reapply last stash
git stash drop          # Delete last stash
Advanced
git log --oneline --graph   # Compact commit history
git diff                    # See unstaged changes
git remote -v               # List remotes
git fetch                   # Fetch remote changes (no merge)
git cherry-pick <commit_id> # Apply specific commit

75034da6-9afb-4b4d-aef2-2537e6a9138d.chunk_text:
git rebase -i HEAD~3        # Interactive rebase (edit last 3 commits)
Pro Tips
Use git status often — it’s your best friend.
Keep commit messages short & meaningful.
Push & pull regularly to avoid conflicts.
Use branches for new features → merge → delete branch.

14b4d26b-09a1-4f54-b10a-533504e65125.chunk_text:
Git Cheat Sheet (Terminal)
Setup
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
Starting a Project
git init                # Initialize a new repo
git clone <url>         # Clone an existing repo
Basic Workflow
git status              # See repo status
git add <file>          # Stage a file
git add .               # Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg"     # Commit with message
git push origin main    # Push changes to remote
git pull origin main    # Pull latest changes
Branching
git branch              # List branches
git branch new-branch   # Create branch
git checkout new-branch # Switch branch
git checkout -b feature # Create + switch
git merge feature       # Merge branch into current
git branch -d feature   # Delete branch
Undo & Fix
git reset --hard HEAD~1     # Undo last commit (dangerous)
git reset --soft HEAD~1     # Undo last commit but keep changes staged
git restore <file>          # Discard changes in a file
git checkout <commit_id>    # Move to old commit (detached HEAD)
Stash
git stash               # Stash current changes
git stash list          # Show stashes
git stash apply         # Reapply last stash
git stash drop          # Delete last stash
Advanced
git log --oneline --graph   # Compact commit history
git diff                    # See unstaged changes
git remote -v               # List remotes
git fetch                   # Fetch remote changes (no merge)
git cherry-pick <commit_id> # Apply specific commit

9b78aa59-9d32-40ae-8a89-1abebb2cd3fd.chunk_text:
git rebase -i HEAD~3        # Interactive rebase (edit last 3 commits)
Pro Tips
Use git status often — it’s your best friend.
Keep commit messages short & meaningful.
Push & pull regularly to avoid conflicts.
Use branches for new features → merge → delete branch.

d91344a1-c095-47a1-a32a-33960efa1d66.chunk_text:
Ubuntu / Linux Essential Command Guide for Developers
This document is a no-nonsense, practical command reference for Ubuntu and Linux users. If you touch
servers, containers, code, or terminals, these commands are mandatory knowledge.
1. File & Folder Management
pwd → Show current directory
ls → List files
ls -la → List all files with permissions
cd folder_name → Enter folder
cd .. → Go back one level
cd ~ → Go to home directory
mkdir folder → Create folder
mkdir -p parent/child/grandchild → Create nested folders
touch file.txt → Create empty file
cp file.txt dest/ → Copy file
cp -r folder dest/ → Copy folder
mv file.txt newname.txt → Rename file
mv file.txt folder/ → Move file
rm file.txt → Delete file
rm -r folder → Delete folder
rm -rf folder → Force delete (danger)
stat file.txt → File details
tree → Folder structure view
2. Locate Files & Folders
find / -name file.txt → Search file system
find . -type f → Find files
find . -type d → Find folders
locate file.txt → Fast search (needs updatedb)
updatedb → Update locate database
which python → Command binary location
whereis python → Binary, source, man page
3. File Viewing & Editing
cat file.txt → View file
less file.txt → Scroll view
head file.txt → First 10 lines
tail file.txt → Last 10 lines
tail -f log.txt → Live log view
nano file.txt → Edit (beginner)
vim file.txt → Edit (pro)
code . → Open VS Code
4. Permissions & Ownership
chmod 755 file.sh → Change permissions
chmod +x script.sh → Make executable
chown user:user file.txt → Change owner
ls -l → View permissions
5. Package Management (APT)
sudo apt update → Refresh repo
sudo apt upgrade → Upgrade system
sudo apt install git → Install package

d8a4ae43-c2c0-43a1-bc00-8c5120064d8f.chunk_text:
sudo apt remove git → Remove package
sudo apt purge git → Remove config too
apt search nginx → Search package
apt show nginx → Package info
sudo apt autoremove → Cleanup
6. Install .deb File (Downloaded from Website)
cd ~/Downloads
sudo dpkg -i app.deb → Install deb
sudo apt -f install → Fix dependencies
sudo dpkg -r app → Remove deb app
7. System Info & Monitoring
uname -a → Kernel info
lsb_release -a → OS info
df -h → Disk usage
du -sh folder → Folder size
free -h → RAM usage
top / htop → Process monitor
uptime → System runtime
whoami → Current user
8. Networking
ip a → Network interfaces
ip route → Routing table
ping google.com → Test internet
curl url → API call
wget url → Download file
ss -tuln → Open ports
netstat -tuln → Legacy port list
9. Process Management
ps aux → All processes
kill PID → Kill process
kill -9 PID → Force kill
pkill process → Kill by name
bg / fg → Background / foreground
10. Environment & Shell
env → Environment variables
export VAR=value → Set variable
echo $VAR → Read variable
history → Command history
clear → Clear terminal
alias ll='ls -la' → Shortcut
source ~/.bashrc → Reload config
11. Compression & Archives
tar -czvf file.tar.gz folder/
tar -xzvf file.tar.gz
zip -r file.zip folder/
unzip file.zip
12. Disk & Mount
lsblk → Disk list

a7d0f2cf-b23f-440c-839d-ab70e27d0ac5.chunk_text:
Git Cheat Sheet (Terminal)
Setup
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
Starting a Project
git init                # Initialize a new repo
git clone <url>         # Clone an existing repo
Basic Workflow
git status              # See repo status
git add <file>          # Stage a file
git add .               # Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg"     # Commit with message
git push origin main    # Push changes to remote
git pull origin main    # Pull latest changes
Branching
git branch              # List branches
git branch new-branch   # Create branch
git checkout new-branch # Switch branch
git checkout -b feature # Create + switch
git merge feature       # Merge branch into current
git branch -d feature   # Delete branch
Undo & Fix
git reset --hard HEAD~1     # Undo last commit (dangerous)
git reset --soft HEAD~1     # Undo last commit but keep changes staged
git restore <file>          # Discard changes in a file
git checkout <commit_id>    # Move to old commit (detached HEAD)
Stash
git stash               # Stash current changes
git stash list          # Show stashes
git stash apply         # Reapply last stash
git stash drop          # Delete last stash
Advanced
git log --oneline --graph   # Compact commit history
git diff                    # See unstaged changes
git remote -v               # List remotes
git fetch                   # Fetch remote changes (no merge)
git cherry-pick <commit_id> # Apply specific commit

31b219ce-e059-411d-a052-f27371c4efb4.chunk_text:
git rebase -i HEAD~3        # Interactive rebase (edit last 3 commits)
Pro Tips
Use git status often — it’s your best friend.
Keep commit messages short & meaningful.
Push & pull regularly to avoid conflicts.
Use branches for new features → merge → delete branch.
